text: left Frank Breyfogle Laporte (February 6, 1880 - September 25, 1939) was an American baseball player. Born in Uhrichsville, Ohio, he began his major league career with the New York Highlanders (present day New York Yankees) in 1905. He was eventually traded to the St. Louis Browns, where he had his best years. In he batted a career-high .314. In LaPorte went to the Indianapolis Hoosiers of the Federal League. He led the league with 107 RBIs in 1914 while batting .311 for the first-place Indianapolis Hoosiers in 1914. His last game was on 10/03/1915. After his season, he retired. In 1194 games over 11 seasons, LaPorte posted a .281 batting average (1185-for-4212) with 501 runs, 198 doubles, 78 triples, 16 home runs, 560 RBI, 101 stolen bases, 288 bases on balls, .331 on-base percentage and .377 slugging percentage. He finished his career with a .944 fielding percentage playing at first, second and third base and all three outfield positions. LaPorte died on September 25, 1939 in Newcomerstown, Ohio. He was buried in Union Cemetery in Uhrichsville, Ohio. ==See also== *List of Major League Baseball annual runs batted in leaders ==External links== * Category:1880 births Category:1939 deaths Category:Baseball players from Ohio Category:Major League Baseball second basemen Category:New York Highlanders players Category:Boston Red Sox players Category:St. Louis Browns players Category:Washington Senators (1901–1960) players Category:Buffalo Bisons (minor league) players Category:Indianapolis Hoosiers players Category:Newark Peppers players Category:People from Uhrichsville, Ohio
title: Frank LaPorte
